node.statement: Algebraic Characterization: A rational function R(q^{-s}) in C(q^{-s}) is finite and nonzero for all s in C if and only if R is a nonzero monomial c q^{-ks} for some c in C* and k in Z. Proof: the map s -> q^{-s} surjects onto C*, and the only rational functions with no zeros or poles on C* are monomials. Combined with JPSS theory (the Rankin-Selberg integral extends to a rational function in q^{-s}), our goal reduces to showing the integral equals a nonzero monomial.
